div.p: In this paper, we exploit the robust H ∞ sliding-mode controller design problem for discrete-time Markovian jump linear systems which are subject to intermittent observations and partially known transition probabilities. The intermittent measurements are described by a Bernoulli process and the phenomenon of the partially known transition probabilities is modeled by employing the polytopic uncertainties. A robust mode-dependent estimator is firstly designed to estimate the system states with the intermittent observations. In order to achieve a good transient performance, the circular region is used to constrain the eigenvalues of the filtering error system's system matrix. With the estimated state vector and the derived observer gain, we propose the design method for the sliding-mode controller with a disturbance predictor and analyze the stability of the closed-loop system. Two numerical examples are provided to illustrate the advantages and the efficacy of the proposed method when simultaneously considering the intermittent observations, the system uncertainty, and the external disturbance.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Sliding-mode control (SMC) features the inherent robustness against model uncertainties and external disturbances [1]. Due to these outstanding characteristics from the application perspective, SMC has been widely applied to many applications and received considerable research attention during the past decades [2]. The author in [3] proposed the SMC design principles and applied the principles to the control problem of electric drives. The adaptive sliding controller with self-tuning fuzzy compensation for a vehicle suspension control system was developed in [4]. In [5], the chattering-free SMC was explored and utilized to a class of nonlinear mechanical systems. The SMC was extended to adjust the singular stochastic hybrid systems and uncertain singular timedelay systems in [6,7], respectively. The authors in [8] investigated the design of SMC for stochastic jump systems. With the rapid development of the digital control techniques, the discrete-time SMC has become an attractive field in control theory and applications; see [9,10] and the references therein. Different from the continuous-time SMC [11], in discrete-time SMC, it is difficult to drive the plant states to the desired sliding-mode surface due to the finite sampling rate [12], but to a quasi sliding-mode surface with a quasi sliding-mode band [13][14][15].

Markovian jump linear systems (MJLSs) are appropriate in characterizing a large class of hybrid systems which are subject to abrupt changes in structures; examples include the random failures of the components, sudden disturbances and variations of the environment, and changes of the operating point of a linearized model of a nonlinear system [16], or subject to network-induced delays and packet dropouts in networked control systems [17]. In an MJLS, there are finite operation modes and the subsystem is linear for each mode. The jumps between different modes are governed by a Markov chain which can be determined before the system analysis and synthesis. The past decade has witnessed the increasing attention on MJLSs for different kinds of plants and applications. The control and filtering problems for uncertain MJLS were reported in [18,19]. For delayed systems, the authors in [20,21] exploited the mode-dependent controllers' or filters' designs. However, if the number of the modes in an MJLS is large and the jumping characteristic is varying during the operations, it is difficult to get the precise transition probabilities of the Markov chain. It is therefore necessary to investigate the MJLS with partially known transition probabilities, which are more general [22][23][24].

In most control and filtering problems, it is generally assumed that the measurements and the observations of the sensors are consecutive. In many practical applications, however, the sensors may have temporary failures during operations, and the controllers do not receive the measurements such as the case in networked control systems. The phenomenon of intermittent observations, also called uncertain observations or missing measurements, was first addressed and modeled in [25]. With the fact that sensors are liable to fail more frequently in harsh industrial environments and the packet dropouts are unavoidable in networked control systems [26], the issue of intermittent observations has attracted particular attention during the past few years; see [27][28][29][30][31][32][33] and the references therein.

Note that the SMC problem for systems which are subject to intermittent observations has both theoretical merits and application values. Yet, there are few results on this topic. The authors in [34] investigated the SMC for systems subject to packet losses. However, it requires that the system matrix should be Schur, that is, all the eigenvalues of the system matrix should be within the unit circle. In this work, we aim to relax such a requirement.

In this paper, we consider the SMC problem for MJLS subject to intermittent observations and partially known transition probabilities. The systems are more generalized than the ones in [34]. The partially known transition probabilities are depicted by using the polytope with finite vertices. We propose a new design scenario for the SMC systems subject to intermittent observations. Considering the intermittent measurements, a Bernoulli process is employed to represent the phenomenon. Since the state is critical in the SMC design, a mode-dependent Luenberger estimator is firstly designed to estimate the system state at the controller side. The emerging challenge is that the system uncertainties, the external disturbance, and a stochastic variable are all involved in the filtering error system. In order to attenuate the effect of those noise and tackle with the stochastic variable, the stochastic stability and the weighted H ∞ performance are introduced. The sliding mode surface is constructed as a proportional term plus an integral term. Compared with the traditional proportional one, the integral SMC is more flexible. Based on the analysis results on the dynamics of the proposed sliding-mode surface, the slidingmode control law is developed. In the simulation section, the Monte Carlo experiments are carried out to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Comparison studies are also presented. Notation: The notations used in this paper are fairly standard. Superscript 'T' and '-1' indicate matrix transposition and inverse, respectively; diag{•} is a diagonal matrix with the diagonal element {•}; l 2 [0, ∞) is the space of square-norm infinite vectors, and for ω ∈ l 2 [0, ∞), and the 2-norm is given by ∥ω∥ 2 =   ∞ k=0 ∥ω k ∥ 2 . In addition, in symmetric block matrices or long matrix expressions, we use * as an ellipsis for the terms that are introduced by symmetry. Matrices, if their dimensions are not explicitly stated, are assumed to be compatible for algebraic operations.

div.p: Consider the following uncertain discrete-time Markovian jump system:
div.formula: x k+1 = (A(r k ) + ∆A(r k , k))x k + B(r k )(u k + f (x k , k)), (1
div.p: where k is the sampling instant, x k ∈ R n denotes the state vector of the system and u k ∈ R m represents the control input. The matrices A(•) and B(•) are constant matrices with appropriate dimensions.

div.head: The norm-bounded uncertainty
div.formula: ∆A(r k , k) satisfies ∆A(r k , k) = E(r k )M(r k , k)H(r k ) with E(•) and H(•) being known constant matrices and M(r k , k) unknown time-varying matrix satisfying M T (r k , k)M(r k , k) < I. f (x k , k) is the external disturbance with a known bound.
div.p: The stochastic process {r k , k ≥ 0} is described via a homogeneous Markov chain which takes values in a finite set S = {1, 2, . . . , s} and the transition mode probability matrix is Λ = [λ ij ]. The element λ ij in the matrix Λ represents the probability jumping from the ith mode to the jth mode, that is,
div.formula: λ ij = Pr(r k+1 = j|r k = i), (2)
div.p: where λ ij , ∀ i, j ∈ S, is a non-negative scalar and  s j=1 λ ij = 1. If each transition probability λ ij is exactly known, the transition probability matrix is a traditional one used in [18]. However, in many practical scenarios, it is questionable to obtain the complete knowledge on the transition probabilities [23]. In this kind of challenging situation, the methodologies on the basis of exactly known transition probabilities are not applicable. In this paper, in order to deal with the partially known transition probabilities, we utilize an uncertain matrix Λ = [λ α i ij ] to characterize the transition probabilities. Here, the uncertain matrix Λ = [λ α i ij ] has the following feature:

In a traditional good sampling environment, it is always assumed that the measurements of the states are ideal. Whereas, this assumption may not hold in a harsh sampling environment. In this paper, we assume that the signals from the plant are subject to intermittent observations [34]. It is practical to assume that the scenario of intermittent observations can be characterized by a Bernoulli process with a probability β for the successful transmission [25], and the signals utilized at the controller node can be accordingly expressed as xk =

If the packet is received, then θ k takes the value 1. Otherwise, the data packet is lost. Remark 1. In this paper, we assume that the Markov mode is detectable and the mode information is wholly shared with the observer and the controller, that is, the observer and the controller are both mode-dependent. This assumption is reasonable in practice since there is a specific mechanism to detect the mode switching signal in many cases. For the estimation error system in (10), due to the existences of the terms ω 1k and ω 2k , we assume that both ω 1k and ω 2k are l 2 -bounded, that is, these terms will not affect the stability of the estimation error system. Similar assumptions can be seen in [39,40] in which the control inputs were assumed to be l 2 -bounded. Generally, the control inputs are state-related in the feedback control. However, with this assumption, the control inputs were taken as the external inputs in [39,40]. In order to increase the stability margin, we have further imposed a smaller stability region (circular region within the unit circle disk) for the estimation error system in (10). Since the uncertainty terms are not dominating in the main dynamics, a smaller circular region would compensate for the effects of ω 1k and ω 2k to the system stability.
Thus, the assumption on the l 2 -boundness is achievable.

Remark 2. In the traditional H ∞ filtering and control [41][42][43][44], the primary object is to design a filter or a controller such that the filtering error or the controlled output satisfies ∥e∥ 2 < γ ∥ω∥ 2 .

However, in this paper, there are two different kinds of external inputs, we employ the weighted H ∞ performance in (11). For different weighting factors, the H ∞ performance index would be different.

Remark 3. In the conventional sliding mode control [3], the main issue is the chattering phenomenon in the control signal which is mainly induced by the sign function of the sliding mode surface. However, in the integral sliding mode control, this phenomenon is eliminated since the sign function is avoided. Therefore, the integral sliding mode control has attracted increasing attention during the past few years; see [2,[45][46][47][48]6] for continuous-time systems and [49] for the sampled-data system. There are relatively fewer results on the discrete-time systems. In this paper, the slide mode surface in ( 27) is a counterpart discrete-time form of the one in [6]. With the special form of the sliding mode surface in (27), the equivalent control law is simple and the chattering phenomenon is omitted.

Remark 4. In the sliding mode surface in (27), there is a prescribed matrix G which is chosen such that the multiplication GB(r k ) is nonsingular for all the possible values of r k . It is obvious that there would be a huge number of choices for the parameter G if B(r k ) is mode-independent. However, there is a variable F (r k ) to be tuned in the sliding mode surface, the choice of G has few impact on the overall system dynamics. For the simplicity of the choice, in this paper, if the input matrix is mode-independent, we can choose G as (B T B) -1 B T . For practical systems, the jumping parameters are always only involved in the system matrix. Therefore, the proposed method has good application potential. If the input matrix is modedependent, we have GB i = GB j = I, ∀i, j = 1, . . . , s. To guarantee the existence of G, one gets B T i B j = 0, ∀i, j = 1, . . . , s, and i ̸ = j.
In summary, the proposed method is applicable for two kinds of Markovian jump linear systems: input-matrix-mode-independent and input-matrix-mode-dependent with B T i B j = 0, ∀i, j = 1, . . . , s.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this work, we have proposed a new SMC design method for Markovian jump systems subject to intermittent observations and partially known transition probabilities. In order to derive the system state which is important in the sliding-mode controller design, a robust mode-dependent H ∞ Luenberger estimator was designed. To deal with multiple noises, a weighted H ∞ performance was introduced. With the estimated state, the integral sliding-mode surface and the sliding-mode control law were established. Finally, two simulation examples were presented to illustrate the advantages and the effectiveness of the proposed design method.
